articles.headline: Falling Short of A+
articles.snippet: Dell is trying to bounce back from a bad year and is now willing to question just about anything.
articles.abstract: Dell is trying to bounce back from a bad year and is now willing to question just about anything.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROUND ROCK, Tex., June 9 — Kevin B. Rollins, the chief executive of Dell, does not want to dwell on what has gone wrong for the last year at his company, the world's largest computer maker. He calls it "wallowing."

articles.headline: A Flash Drive That Holds Your Computer
articles.snippet: Lexar PowerToGo software is designed to turn a flash drive into a portable Windows XP ecosystem.
articles.abstract: Lexar PowerToGo software is designed to turn a flash drive into a portable Windows XP ecosystem.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOUR digital life spins at 7,200 rotations a minute on your computer's hard drive. A delicate reading arm, hovering a fraction of an inch above the surface of the drive's spinning platters, dances across them at 60 miles an hour; one bump, and your files are toast. Your hard drive's likelihood of mechanical failure is 100 percent; it's just a matter of when.

articles.headline: After Iraq Visit, an Upbeat Bush Urges Patience
articles.snippet: Seeking political momentum, President Bush warned Democrats that an early withdrawal of troops would set back counterterrorism efforts.
articles.abstract: Seeking political momentum, President Bush warned Democrats that an early withdrawal of troops would set back counterterrorism efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 14 — Seeking political momentum from his surprise trip to Baghdad, President Bush said Wednesday that Iraqis feared "America will lose its nerve," and pointedly warned Democrats that an early withdrawal of troops would set back counterterrorism efforts and "endanger our country."

articles.headline: Jihadist or Victim: Ex-Detainee Makes a Case
articles.snippet: Moazzam Begg, a former Guantánamo detainee, has emerged over the last few months as a minor celebrity.
articles.abstract: Moazzam Begg, a former Guantánamo detainee, has emerged over the last few months as a minor celebrity.
articles.lead_paragraph: When President Bush ordered Moazzam Begg's release last year from the Guantánamo prison camp, United States officials say, he did so over objections from the Pentagon, the C.I.A. and the F.B.I. — all of which warned that Mr. Begg could still be a dangerous terrorist.

articles.headline: A Modest Rise Still Amplifies Inflation Fears
articles.snippet: Why is an underlying inflation rate of less than 3 percent so alarming?
articles.abstract: Why is an underlying inflation rate of less than 3 percent so alarming?
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 14 — Twenty-five years ago, any hint that basic consumer prices were climbing less than 3 percent a year would have struck most people as impossibly good news.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Asked Grasso if He Buoyed Stock
articles.snippet: Richard A. Grasso faced questions from regulators about whether he prodded traders to support the A.I.G.'s share price while he was head of the New York Stock Exchange.
articles.abstract: Richard A. Grasso faced questions from regulators about whether he prodded traders to support the A.I.G.'s share price while he was head of the New York Stock Exchange.
articles.lead_paragraph: Richard A. Grasso, the former chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange, faced questions from federal regulators about whether he prodded traders to support the American International Group's share price while he was head of the exchange and its regulatory unit, government documents released yesterday disclosed.

articles.headline: Jihadist or Victim: Ex-Detainee Makes a Case
articles.snippet: When President Bush ordered Moazzam Begg's release last year from the Guantánamo prison camp, United States officials say, he did so over objections from the Pentagon, the C.I.A. and the F.B.I. -- all of which warned that Mr. Begg could still be a...
articles.abstract: When President Bush ordered Moazzam Begg's release last year from the Guantánamo prison camp, United States officials say, he did so over objections from the Pentagon, the C.I.A. and the F.B.I. -- all of which warned that Mr. Begg could still be a dangerous terrorist.     But American officials may not have imagined the sort of adversary Mr. Begg would become in the war of perception that is now a primary front in the American-led campaign against terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: When President Bush ordered Moazzam Begg's release last year from the Guantánamo prison camp, United States officials say, he did so over objections from the Pentagon, the C.I.A. and the F.B.I. -- all of which warned that Mr. Begg could still be a dangerous terrorist.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Asked Grasso if He Buoyed Stock
articles.snippet: Richard A. Grasso, the former chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange, faced questions from federal regulators about whether he prodded traders to support the American International Group's share price while he was head of the exchange and ...
articles.abstract: Richard A. Grasso, the former chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange, faced questions from federal regulators about whether he prodded traders to support the American International Group's share price while he was head of the exchange and its regulatory unit, government documents released yesterday disclosed.     During Mr. Grasso's deposition, given before the Securities and Exchange Commission in June 2005, he repeatedly invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination, in spite of warnings from S.E.C. lawyers that doing so could be used against him in a civil case.
articles.lead_paragraph: Richard A. Grasso, the former chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange, faced questions from federal regulators about whether he prodded traders to support the American International Group's share price while he was head of the exchange and its regulatory unit, government documents released yesterday disclosed.

articles.headline: A Modest Rise Still Amplifies Inflation Fears
articles.snippet: Twenty-five years ago, any hint that basic consumer prices were climbing less than 3 percent a year would have struck most people as impossibly good news.     Paul A. Volcker, the towering, cigar-chomping Federal Reserve chairman who is widely cre...
articles.abstract: Twenty-five years ago, any hint that basic consumer prices were climbing less than 3 percent a year would have struck most people as impossibly good news.     Paul A. Volcker, the towering, cigar-chomping Federal Reserve chairman who is widely credited with breaking the spiral of double-digit inflation that began in the 1970's, saw consumer prices climb less than 3 percent during only one year of his tenure.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 14 - Twenty-five years ago, any hint that basic consumer prices were climbing less than 3 percent a year would have struck most people as impossibly good news.

articles.headline: That Wild Streak? Maybe It Runs in the Family
articles.snippet: Jason Dallas used to think of his daredevil streak -- a love of backcountry skiing, mountain bikes and fast vehicles -- as ''a personality thing.''      Then he heard that scientists at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle had lin...
articles.abstract: Jason Dallas used to think of his daredevil streak -- a love of backcountry skiing, mountain bikes and fast vehicles -- as ''a personality thing.''      Then he heard that scientists at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle had linked risk-taking behavior in mice to a gene. Those without it pranced unprotected along a steel beam instead of huddling in safety like the other mice.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jason Dallas used to think of his daredevil streak -- a love of backcountry skiing, mountain bikes and fast vehicles -- as "a personality thing."

articles.headline: Falling Short of A+
articles.snippet: Kevin B. Rollins, the chief executive of Dell, does not want to dwell on what has gone wrong for the last year at his company, the world's largest computer maker. He calls it ''wallowing.''      When pressed for an explanation of why revenue growt...
articles.abstract: Kevin B. Rollins, the chief executive of Dell, does not want to dwell on what has gone wrong for the last year at his company, the world's largest computer maker. He calls it ''wallowing.''      When pressed for an explanation of why revenue growth has slowed drastically and why profits have fallen, his explanation is short. ''We got a little too far ahead on profit, and that allowed competitors to sneak in,'' he said in an interview at the company's headquarters here, referring to Dell's profit-margin goals. ''Our competitors got better, and that allowed them to get strong.''
articles.lead_paragraph: ROUND ROCK, Tex., June 9 - Kevin B. Rollins, the chief executive of Dell, does not want to dwell on what has gone wrong for the last year at his company, the world's largest computer maker. He calls it "wallowing."

articles.headline: NYSE's Coup Stirs Political Opposition in Europe
articles.snippet: A trans-Atlantic deal that looked like a strategic coup for the newly public NYSE Group -- its proposed acquisition of the pan-European stock exchange Euronext -- appears to be turning into a quagmire.     The NYSE Group's traction has slipped as ...
articles.abstract: A trans-Atlantic deal that looked like a strategic coup for the newly public NYSE Group -- its proposed acquisition of the pan-European stock exchange Euronext -- appears to be turning into a quagmire.     The NYSE Group's traction has slipped as politicians in Europe have lined up in favor of a domestic alternative to the deal. The opposition reflects fears among European companies that they might be subject to American securities regulations if the acquisition is completed.
articles.lead_paragraph: A trans-Atlantic deal that looked like a strategic coup for the newly public NYSE Group -- its proposed acquisition of the pan-European stock exchange Euronext -- appears to be turning into a quagmire.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Heather Timmons

articles.headline: At Tribune, a Call for a Split
articles.snippet: A boardroom feud at the Tribune Company escalated yesterday as the Chandler family, Tribune's second-largest investor, called for a breakup of the company in a new example of pressure being applied to a struggling newspaper business.     In a lett...
articles.abstract: A boardroom feud at the Tribune Company escalated yesterday as the Chandler family, Tribune's second-largest investor, called for a breakup of the company in a new example of pressure being applied to a struggling newspaper business.     In a letter sent to the company's board, trustees representing the Chandler family -- the billionaire former owners of The Los Angeles Times -- accused Tribune management of pursuing a failed strategy for melding local TV stations and newspapers and failing to keep pace with industry rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: A boardroom feud at the Tribune Company escalated yesterday as the Chandler family, Tribune's second-largest investor, called for a breakup of the company in a new example of pressure being applied to a struggling newspaper business.
articles.byline: By Richard Siklos and Katharine Q. Seelye

articles.headline: A Flash Drive That Holds Your Computer
articles.snippet: YOUR digital life spins at 7,200 rotations a minute on your computer's hard drive. A delicate reading arm, hovering a fraction of an inch above the surface of the drive's spinning platters, dances across them at 60 miles an hour; one bump, and you...
articles.abstract: YOUR digital life spins at 7,200 rotations a minute on your computer's hard drive. A delicate reading arm, hovering a fraction of an inch above the surface of the drive's spinning platters, dances across them at 60 miles an hour; one bump, and your files are toast. Your hard drive's likelihood of mechanical failure is 100 percent; it's just a matter of when.      And this is how society has chosen to preserve its future?
articles.lead_paragraph: YOUR digital life spins at 7,200 rotations a minute on your computer's hard drive. A delicate reading arm, hovering a fraction of an inch above the surface of the drive's spinning platters, dances across them at 60 miles an hour; one bump, and your files are toast. Your hard drive's likelihood of mechanical failure is 100 percent; it's just a matter of when.

articles.headline: After Iraq Visit, an Upbeat Bush Urges Patience
articles.snippet: Seeking political momentum from his surprise trip to Baghdad, President Bush said Wednesday that Iraqis feared ''America will lose its nerve,'' and pointedly warned Democrats that an early withdrawal of troops would set back counterterrorism effor...
articles.abstract: Seeking political momentum from his surprise trip to Baghdad, President Bush said Wednesday that Iraqis feared ''America will lose its nerve,'' and pointedly warned Democrats that an early withdrawal of troops would set back counterterrorism efforts and ''endanger our country.''     Mr. Bush, speaking at a news conference in the Rose Garden just hours after his 3 a.m. return from Baghdad, promised to send American diplomats to Europe, Asia and the Middle East to press countries there to make good on $13 billion in pledges toward Iraq reconstruction. So far, only about $3 billion has been paid, and some donors have expressed concerns that their money would be spent on security, not rebuilding.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 14 - Seeking political momentum from his surprise trip to Baghdad, President Bush said Wednesday that Iraqis feared "America will lose its nerve," and pointedly warned Democrats that an early withdrawal of troops would set back counterterrorism efforts and "endanger our country."
